module.p: Gàidheal Gael, member of the Goidelic race, Highlander, Gaelic-speaker is a masculine ethnonymic common noun, with genitive singular Gàidheil and (nominative/dative) plural Gàidheil.

Pedagogical examples –
Cànan nan Gàidheal
The Language of the Gaels td. 201 song title; note genitive plural
Note: Na Gàidheil The Gaels as an ethnonymic name description.
Gàidhealach pertaining to the Gaels or the Highlands is an adjective derived from the noun Gàidheal with suffix -(e)ach.

Pedagogical examples –
geamannan Gàidhealach
Highland games td. 201
An Comunn Gàidhealach The Highland Society is an ergonymic name description.
Gàidhlig is a (feminine) glottonymic proper noun derived from the noun Gàidheal, with genitive singular Gàidhlige (though the final -e is almost always dropped in all but the most formal usage).

Pedagogical examples –
Tha Gàidhlig agam. / cuir Gàidhlig air Beurla / bruidhinn Gàidhlig / Is e facal Gàidhlig a th’ ann.
I speak Gaelic. / translate English into Gaelic / speak Gaelic / It’s a Gaelic word. td. 201
Tha Gàidhlig aige. / ’S e faclair Gàidhlig a th’ ann. / facail Ghàidhlig
He knows Gaelic; he can speak Gaelic. / It’s a Gaelic dictionary. / Gaelic words td. 322

Compounds –
Gàidhlig Mhanainneach Manx
Gàidhlig ghnàthasach idiomatic Gaelic
As with other glottonymic proper nouns, Gàidhlig often occurs with the definite article (as an ‘uncommon/improper’ noun).

Pedagogical examples –
bruidhinn sa Ghàidhlig
speak Gaelic td. 201
luchd na Gàidhlig
Gaelic people, Gaelic speakers td. 201
Comunn na Gàidhlig The Gaelic Society is an ergonymic name description, with acronym CNAG / CnaG / Cnag.
Gàidhealtachd a Gaeldom, area where Gaels live is a feminine toponymic common noun derived from the noun Gàidheal, with genitive singular Gàidhealtachd and plural form Gàidhealtachdan.
A’ Ghàidhealtachd Gaeldom, The Highlands is a toponymic name description.

Pedagogical examples –
Roinn na Gàidhealtachd
Highland Region td. 201 toponymic name description
air (a’) Ghàidhealtachd
in the Highlands td. 201

Examples from modern usage –
’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn. Rinn e sin tro dhìcheall, obair chruaidh agus tàlant malairt a bha neo-ghnàthach. An-diugh tha iomadh companaidh na ainm air feadh na Gàidhealtachd. [...]
Thomas is the only crofter I know who has risen to the status of a tycoon. He did that through duty, hard work and a talent for business that was unusual. Today there are many companies in his name all over the Highlands. [...] td. 5
